summary: human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1) infection triggers host immune responses by increasing the expression of a number of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines. these chemokines are one of the major coordinators that regulate the immune response during HIV-1 pathogenesis. they either participate in host defense or contribute toward disease progression. HIV-1 invades the CNS during the early phase of infection through migrating perivascular monocytes/macrophages and lymphocytes. this upregulation of cytokines and chemokines by the virus and viral proteins is mediated by signaling molecules. HIV-1-induced phosphorylation of ERK1/2 and p38 increases expression of cytokines and chemokines in multiple cell types. gp120 activates c-Jun amino-terminal kinase/stress-activated protein kinase and p38. also, chemokines CCL2 and MIP-1 stimulates the production of CCL5 in astrocytes. phosphorylation of MAPK kinases results in infiltration of neutrophil into tissue compartments. human recombinant IL-1 and neutralizing antibody against IL-1 were purchased from millipore. ERK1/2, p38, and SAPK/JNK inhibitors were purchased from Abcam. 3 mL of Histopaque 1077 was layered on 3 mL of histopaque 1119. 6 mL blood was layered on top of the Histopaque layers. the tube was centrifuged at 890 g for 30 min at 20°C. supernatants were collected, spun at 3,000 rpm for 10 min, and filtered through a 0.22 m filter to remove cellular debris. differentiated (7–8 day old) MDMs were either infected with HIV-1 at a multiplicity of infection. the cDNA product was used to perform gene expression array using a Taqman 7900HT machine. data were normalized with endogenous controls (included in the array) and differential regulation of proinflammatory chemokines (fold change) was analyzed from the Ct values. treatment of neuronal cell lines and primary neurons and apoptosis analyses Briefly, primary neurons (3104 cells/well) as well as NT2 and SH-SY5Y cells were exposed to HIV-1- or mock-infected MDM supernatants. to detect neuronal apoptosis, cells were washed twice with 1PBS and were stained with the JC-1 staining solution. supernatants were harvested at 48–72 h postinfection. chemotaxis assay was used to monitor migration of neutrophils. blots were washed twice HIV-1 regulates the expression of CXCL5 through IL-1 in infected MDMs. IL-1 triggers the expression of CXCL5 through IL-1 in different cell types. mRNA transcript analyses indicate that IL-1 and CXCL5 have parallel expression pattern. supernatants were harvested at 3, 6, 12, and 24 h postinfection. hek293T cells were treated with 1, 10, or 20 ng of recombinant human interleukin-1 or MDM supernatants from HIV-1-infected and mock-infected cultures. reporter activity measured posttreatment exhibited a dose-dependent increase in CXCL5 promoter activity by rhIL-1 stimulation compared with no stimulation. a significantly higher level of luciferase gene expression was also observed in these cells treated with HIV-1-infected MDM supernatants compared with mock-infected supernatants. was assessed in HIV-1-exposed/infected and control MDM cell lysates. results indicate a significant increase in phosphorylation of ERK1/2 and p38 within 30 min postexposure in HIV-1-treated MDMs compared with mock-treated culture. but SAPK/JNK showed no significant difference between these groups. MDMs treated with vehicle (DMSO) were considered negative control. increased phosphorylation of ERK1/2 and p38 is associated with upregulation of CXCL5 in HIV-1-infected MDMs. a chemotaxis assay was performed with a CXCR2 (receptor for CXCL5 ligand)-expressing cell line (L1.2 cells) as well as primary neutrophils using HIV-1-infected or mock-infected MDM supernatants. at a concentration of 1 nM rhCXCL5, the number of migrated L1.2 cells was 12 times higher compared with mock. however, at 10 nM there was no additional blocking of CXCL5 reduced neutrophil migration by 30% in control MDM supernatants. reduction was 65% in HIV-1-positive MDM culture supernatants (P=0.0161) results indicate that CXCL5 plays a major role in recruitment of neutrophils. neuronal cell lines NT2, SH-SY5Y, and NP cells were treated with HIV-1- or mock-infected MDM supernatants. cell death in neuronal cells exposed to control MDM supernatant ranged between 8% to 13% in NT2 and SH-SY5Y cells and 17% in primary neurons. blocking of CXCL5 did not have any significant effect on neuronal survival. induced differential regulation of chemokines in MDMs role in HIV-1-induced neuropathogenesis. normal donor-derived MDMs were infected with HIV-1 at an MOI of 0.1 or mock infected. compared with mock-infected controls, HIV-1-infected MDMs expressed a number of chemokines at different time points postinfection. in HIV-1-infected MDMs Compared with Mock-Infected Control Cell Gene symbol Day 1 Day 2 Day 3 Day 4 Day 8 Day 12 Day 16 Day 20 CCL1 47.1821 16.3458 — — 4.4766 — 3.932 — CCL2 4.8856 3.3757 — — — — 3.1553 — 2.1894 CCL3 4.5349 2.3376 — — — — 2.4965 2.8851 CCL — — 2.7078 — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — positive values indicate upregulation and negative values downregulation of inflammatory chemokine genes in HIV-1-infected MDMs compared with mock. qRT-PCR, quantitative real-time PCR, quantitative real-time PCR. HIV-1-infected MDM supernatants. natants (P=0.0161) indicate that CXCL5 plays a major role in recruitment of neutrophils and cells expressing CXCR2 receptor. transmigration of L1.2 cells in response to HIV-1 or mock-infected MDM supernatants was assessed by chemotaxis assay. cell death in neuronal cells exposed to control MDM supernatant ranged between 8% to 13% in NT2 and SH-SY5Y cells and 17% in primary neurons. cell death increased to 21%–25% in case of NT2 and SH-SY5Y and 37% in primary neurons. blocking of CXCL5 did not have any significant effect on neuronal survival. infection both in vitro and in vivo as well as by other viruses. association of CXCL1 and CXCL5 in the west Nile Virus induced encephalitis through IL-22 was reported. IL-1 is known to be regulated by HIV-1 as part of the proinflammatory response both in vivo and in vitro. expression of inflammatory cytokines/chemokines and immune activation are hallmarks of HIV-1-associated diseases. inflammatory response in infected individuals remains high, suggesting an interaction between HIV-1 particles and signaling molecules. this interaction could potentially alter signaling events that trigger the release of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines. ERK1/2 is related to CXCL5 production is not established. it is possible to predict that phosphorylation of ERK1/2 could phosphorylate or translocate transcription factors and/or IL-1 that could potentially bind and transactivate the CXCL5 promoter. CXCL5 primarily contributes to the movement of neutrophils or CXCR2-positive cells. it is possible to predict that the virus may have a role in infiltration of other cell types. hyperactivation of neutrophils in HIV-1-infected patients is associated with deregulation of the apoptosis/necrosis equilibrium.
